item.title: BPE Tokenization Demystified: Implementation and Examples
item.author: MartinLwx
item.description: A taxonomy of tokenization methods In NLP, one crux of problems is - how to tokenize the text. There are three methods available: Char-level Word-level Subword-level Let’s talk about the Char-level tokenizer. That is, we tokenize the text into a char stream. For instance, highest -> h, i, g, h, e, s, t. One advantage of the Char-level tokenizer is that the size of Vocab won’t be that large. The size of Vocab is equal to the size of the alphabet.

item.title: TF-IDF model
item.author: MartinLwx
item.description: What is the TF-IDF model In previous post, we talked about the bag-of-word model, which has many limitations. Today we take a step further to see if we can try to fix one of the limitations - Each word has the same importance. ðŸ’¡ The crux of the problem - How to define the word importance? One idea is: The more frequently a word appears within a single document, the more important it is for that document.

item.title: Bag-of-Word model
item.author: MartinLwx
item.description: What is the bag-of-word model? In NLP, we need to represent each document as a vector because machine learning can only accept input as numbers.
